Posts.Content: Hi jacks77 -I am at the same stage as you. I had nausea during my first few sessions and my GP prescribed some anti- sickness, but this could have been more due to my motion sickness (they have to move the bed through 90deg a few times) than because of the Therapy. I have felt very tired and sometimes queasy in the evenings, but this has worn off over the weekend. Start again on Monday so will have to see how it goes. Best of luck - hope it improves for you.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi There Just to say I have managed to continue to exercise too, for a mood and body booster! :+) I moved my exercise bike into my bedroom so that it is there as a reminder morning and evening. I usually manage 20 mins at different paces depending on where I am in the cycle and sometimes go on to use my cross trainer afterwards building up to the next dose. I then go for a 'cooling' and revitalising 'stomp' for about 3-5k in the lanes around my house sometimes with a little 'trot' up the hilly bits (I used to run the 5k and am looking forward to starting again in the spring -with this weather running in snow boots is different :+) - although I believe one of the African runners trained in hob nail boots! - so maybe there is hope for me yet!) I am pacing myself at work mainly because the one hour commute is in heavy, fast (60-80mph) traffic, with lots of side roads joining (and yes people do pull straight out!) and then very slow city traffic with lots of hargy- bargy and while I am on the post chemo anti emetics and steroids I am a little off my head and feel a possible accident is avoided by not driving on those days. I am also taking one or two extra days to fit in some nice things to mood boost. I have also arranged for Weds (I work Mon- Fri) so that I have a 'rest' day in the middle of my week - it is also my PICC line day and I try to arrange Oncology appts then too. This is because I want to give myself the best possible chance to come out the other end feeling ok. It means that I can be chirpy at work so they get a positive vibe from me. I do have to be quite strict with them though and remind them that I need these days or I could deteriorate rapidly and then I wouldn't be any help at all and they would be struggling to cover the workload. I was told by a colleague that this was possibly detrimental to my sick record, but at 60 am I bothered? ;+) This story is meant as a - we are all different and you have to do what's best for you story -meant to reassure and motivate- not as an example. Hope all goes well for everyone :+)
Posts.Title: Ec

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby Rose We are all holding hands with you on this one. The worst waits for were waiting for the definitive results and operation and then between the operation and start of chemo. I felt quite sick with frustration on occasion and worrying not sleeping didn't help. The What Ifs are ghastly. I found it best to remember how I was before I knew and ask myself do I actually - physically feel any different - and I had to say no - physically I was the same - I could still do the things I enjoyed before the investigations and diagnosis so why wouldn't I focus on doing those things now instead of pacing and angsting, so I arranged to do some nice things as a distraction - walks, lunches out, cinema etc. I did phone the breast care nurse with questions between appointments and they were also very reassuring.  The wait will be over soon and they you can make a plans with your husband to get you both through this stronger than before. Best wishes :+)x
Posts.Title: Early cancer plus cancer plus 1 x lymph node treatment— lumpectomy...

Posts.Content: Hi there I am 60 similar diagnosis, but my tumour was only 1.2cm so they did the surgery first. It was classed as grade 2 and as there were cells in the lymph node they removed they suggested FEC chemo(same drugs as you but maybe different amount - I am having 75) and then radiotherapy and then a suitable drug for menopausal women. I had a PICC line put in and have had my chemo hand delivered by a nurse every three weeks. I am having 6 lots the last lot is next week.They administer the chemo from an array of syringes in a private room - they infuse an anti sickness drug through a pump throughout running it throug first for a while and then start to inject the chemo. The whole delivery plus chit chat Takes about 45mins to an hour. I am having my treatment at Torbay Hospital in Devon. The team there are excellent and always make me feel relaxed and welcome and know how to cheer me up. I really do appreciate them. They will also listen and answer questions if I have any. So do talk to your team and ask questions.  I have been really lucky and have had a few of the side effects, but (touch wood) nothing requiring hospitalisation. I have kept a certain level of exercise up (I was reasonably fit when entering this) and force myself to eat and drink (even though the side effects sometimes really make it quite difficult) as I know I need sufficient nutrients and fluid to remain functional and out of hospital! I have also managed to work a reasonable amount which has helped to keep some kind of normality in my life. (I take the week off post chemo and then work MonTues Thurs and Fri - taking the Weds off as a rest day as after 2 full days I feel tired. If you say which hospital you have your chemo through someone might be going through the same thing and you could then have a direct comparison.  Hope everything goes well for you too.
Posts.Title: Is CEF a better regime for locally advanced breast cancer with er...

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlettem I have had 2 lots of FEC and just had my third one today. I do keep myself doing a small amount of exercise most most days and drink plenty (there has been some nurse research that shows that being well hydrated can mitigate side effects in some patients and I know from personal experience, it can make it easier to cannulate) and make sure I eat ok. I do the injections as instructed. On the first round on the 6th night I had what I can only describe as 'contractions' down either side of my pelvis. I took my temperature and pulse as it was normal, I took some paracetamol and then did the same 4-6 hours later with Ibuprofen and alternated them which took the pain away for me, taking my temperature and pulse each time prior to taking anything. I did phone the ward number I had been given and they said that I was doing the right thing at that time so you must phone yourself if you have symptoms a vigilant nurse will add it to the MHRA website as a side effect hopefully! The Oncologist didn't think it caused this kind of effect, but as I wasn't taking anything else at the time and I had seen elsewhere on this site that this had happened to someone else so maybe he had just not come across it before. Reassuringly the symptoms only lasted 24 hours - I woke up at the same time the following night expecting pain and it had gone! yay! The second time around I drank more and upped the exercise and it wasn't as bad or as long - yay- again. You have to do what is right for you and your body though. Hopefully things will go smoothly for you too x
Posts.Title: Filgrastim injections

Posts.Content: Hoping to get mine back at some point, but I am forcing myself to eat and drink to get me through this so won't be until April when I feel like running again! Few pics from the walk today: The tree and gateway are from my pre treatment 5k run- the other two I tried to capture some ice and frost... not so successful, ended up doing 6.23km to detour to take the pics! :+) Trying to do some CPD in front of the computer now....but it is such a gorgeous day out there!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi  Just thought I would share some photos from my walk this morning to show spring is coming - theme new life, new hope Some from an earlier foray in the garden - Fairy grotto :+) Amazing what you can take with an i-phone SE
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: @Penny Lane - dont worry about the plaits I am 60 and was sporting them last year both on my motorbike and at work! They are very 'in' at the moment :+) and I am well familiar with the swishy trouser syndrome! :+) - and helmet hair :+)X @Cannon & What Happened - it takes me ages to do posts as within 5 seconds of sitting in front of a computer I have to get up and do something else, then leave my glasses somewhere and then I have to go looking for them again, so constant motion and no production! :+$ @LeoLady56 we will all be looking to you for profile pictures :+)X Just a couple of pics from my walk today - not so far 4.13km  I sat in the winter sunshine for a few moments and watched the crows/rooks fly from the tower to the tree and back.  More new Life - no doubt the squirrels will be eating the crocus stamens as soon as they appear! I am waiting for it to snow, I would be in Canada with my son snowboarding like last year _ planning to head out for Christmas instead this year now....cant wait to see all that powder again....soooooo soft :+)X
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I know it is wrong of me to tell you to play devils advocat as there maybe something going on in her life that makes her the way she is ......  but the other part of me says 'Go on Go on Go on - you know you really want to!' You could go along and smile a lot and be absolutely charming and that will leave her wondering what you are up to - let her own psyche do the rest - and yes I probably am an evil genius!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I haven't been on for a while as it means starting up my PC and I don't find adding stuff as easy on my i-pad (think I need lessons! Here are some photos of my walk in to work, I park about 1 mile away and walk up the hill and down in the evening crossing over two bridges over the river Exe I will take some better one's in the summer when I start cycling again (lots of lovely cycle paths around there.)                   Best wishes to everyone and those boots were made for walking!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Brilliant idea! When I get out will post pic of primroses in the hedge of my normal walk. :+)x
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Aspen No worries - I have been feeling the same - I was especially down after the 3rd chemo as I was neither at the beginning nor at the end and I did say to the nurse when I went for my PICC line that the 3rd and 4th probably feel worse because you have neither the anticipation and 'I can do this' energy of the start not the way hay almost there of the end so it is bound to feel like a long haul. Sounds like you are doing all the right things to get yourself out - do meet up with friends if possible and chat to anyone on here. Don't compare yourself to others we all have started from different backgrounds and levels of fitness etc., but do take solace in that we are all going through this together! This page of walking back to happiness has been great for me so well done and thank you to Whatshappened for setting it up
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: @ Winney Thank you so much  for posting this link. I think it is very applicable to anyone who has gone through a life changing, event, illness or diagnosis, I am certainly going to take it into work for everyone to read ( I work in Healthcare). I will bear all the information in mind when I get through the 'one day at a time' bit of the treatment! I remember one of my bosses turning to me after my husband died rapidly at 47 over 5 months about 14 years ago, she said 'We will soon have you back to normal' I turned to her and said - 'I'm sorry but after what has happened I don't know what normal is and probably never will.' I know she meant well by her shocked reaction, but obviously had no understanding. I did change my life and found a new career that I love so that I could motivate my teenage sons, showing them that just because life gives you knocks you don't stay down you get up and work them out! I must have worked through the set he talks about in the healing process without even knowing! :+) It is really useful to have it mapped out.  Thank you againX
Posts.Title: Once treatment has finished..getting back “to normal “

Posts.Content: Haha @Winney...I know the feeling - when people have said to me over the years that I haven't changed a bit (from my 20/30's) I look all horrified at them and say -' You mean to say my skin was this saggy and wrinkly then?!' We then go on to have a laugh,but I've made a point! Better to say - I love that colour you are wearing or that jumper really suits you or something else that will boost rather than be an obvious 'there,there.' But do not take me shopping, because I will say if something isn't right rather than let you buy something inappropriate!
Posts.Title: Once treatment has finished..getting back “to normal “

Posts.Content: If it is any consolation, I also got shoved onto a locum who had a terribly dismissive manner; he queried side effects and suggested they were nothing to do with my treatment (although I had read many threads on here about ladies on the same treatment having the same side effects as me as well as it being listed under common side effects on the PIL!) He rushed through everything and didn't listen so I have insisted on seeing the Oncologist I first saw who was lovely and asked questions to confirm information I had given him, different style altogether! I was then told about him being a locum and that he had since left, they seemed to understand when I said his style didn't suit my personality so I think there had been others who had the same reaction as me. Trust your instincts and find someone that suits you. Xx
Posts.Title: Has anyone changed oncologist mid treatment?

Posts.Content: Phone the unit now, don't delay, they are very helpful and will advise you accordingly - they are very proactive at getting you in to get you checked over as infections can develop rapidly and may leave you incapable of phoning later, don't mean to scare you but best to get checked out. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Pain in arm chemo fec was given 9 dsys ago
